  {panel}

Quartz, the scheduling subsystem in Confluence, expects the system clock to work.  If the system clock jumps backwards, then any tasks that were scheduled before the backward jump will not occur until the clock catches up again.

This has happened at least once on a virtualised machine, and was somewhat difficult to track down.  It manifested most obviously as "indexing stops working for a while, then resumes"

Ideally Confluence or Quartz would guard against weird time fluctuations in some way.

(Note that I've put this in the Search/Indexing component because there's no "scheduled jobs" component)
fields.summary: Guard against badly broken system clocks

My team members would add label *myteam* to their user profiles (from pre-populated list or create new ones). On SOAP web services Login request:

What is expected - 

  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
- <loginResponse xmlns="https://wiki.mydomainname.com/rpc/soap-axis/confluenceservice-v1">
     <loginReturn xmlns="">loginReturn</loginReturn>
  </loginResponse>


What is actually coming back -

  <?xml version="1.0" ?> 
- <ns1:loginResponse xmlns:ns1="http://soap.rpc.confluence.atlassian.com" xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" soapenv:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/">

I was actually confused about comments and permalinking until a few minutes ago.

Here's the technique I'd like to see happen with Confluence permalinked comments:

http://www.37signals.com/svn/archives/000558.php

And I'd prefer a *deep yellow* background - almost unreadable, if necessary - or maybe a *deep blue* background - something that _really_ grabs your eyes so you can focus in on the comment you're looking for. We already provide two different colors for our comments, so a highlight color that grabs your attention needs to really be ridiculously eye-catching.

And, this is still not an ideal solution. For instance, I open a lot of new tabs through links - hopefully the fade effect would not kick in until I actually looked at that tab for the first time - often, I open the tab 'in the background' without immediately switch over to view it.

Basically, I thought comment permalinks were broken - I thought we needed to provide a lot of whitespace at the bottom of each page, but I guess this is the new way to do it. I probably would not have been as confused if we really highlighted the comment I was heading to.

Use Javascript to highlight selected comment on permalinks
http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-11903

Example link:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Known+Issues+for+Resin+3.x?focusedCommentId=147187#comment-147187

As there isn't any check on the size, if a user is saving a page bigger than 100,000 characters the database would throw an integrity constraint error.

We need to implement a better check (page size limitation) and a better error message to advise the user if they have breached the page size limit.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12761].

# I find it the currently rendered Template pages with form objects all over the place awful to look at and use.  Consider a long page, with 8 fields spread throughout.  In order to _find_ the fields you have to scroll up and down etc.
# I also find it strange that because the page is rendered, it limits what can be set as a field, for example:
#- macro parameters (this kills Template Fields usage for me)
#- url parameters etc
#- links

In order to support what I am about to suggest, the Template fields would have to be updated to support groupings through a Category value, and to provide a clue as to the fields intended purpose, shown here with a *#* separator char.
h4. Current
{noformat}
||Some field | @fieldname@ |
{noformat}
h4. Proposed
{noformat}
||Some field | @Category1#Field Label text#fieldname@ |
{noformat}

h4. Example form 
{panel:title=Example Form}
h5. Category 1
|| Field Label text | *[FORM ENTRY BOX*|
|| Another Field Label text | *[FORM ENTRY BOX*|
h5. Category 2
|| Field Label text | *[FORM ENTRY BOX*|
|| Another Field Label text | *[FORM ENTRY BOX*|
{panel}

This would then allow pages with complex arrangement of field values to be easily provided without the Junk that appears with dynamically create content.   Also, and most importantly this would allow arbitrary replacement of _any_ text _anywhere_ in the page, solving all related issues about where such values can/cannot be used.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12751].
  {panel}

Add ability to list attachment's physical location when searching for attachments.

For example, in case Lucene indexing is broken, thus unable to search for attachments, provide other means to do so.

The SQL query below locates specific attachment by the file name - show searching for a file with the word 'office' in it's title. The result will show the location on your filesystem as well. 
On Linux you can use the {{file}} command to find out the details about the file. {code}file -i <file_name> {code} will print out the MIME type as well.

{code:sql}
select s.spacekey, s.spacename, a.title, a.pageid, a.attachmentid, '(confluence-home)/attachments/' + a.pageid + '/' + a.attachmentid + '/' + a.attversion as filepath
from attachments a
join content c
    on a.pageid = c.contentid
join spaces s
    on c.spaceid = s.spaceid
where a.title like 'office%
{code}
fields.summary: Locate Attachments

We export spaces to create PDF, XML and/or HTML versions of the space.

At Atlassian, we then provide these versions to the customer. In order to do this, we need to:
* Export the space.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-12689].
  {panel}

(This issue has been brought up several times, but I can't find a JIRA for it, so I'm creating it now)

Confluence clustering allow us to add redundancy and load balancing to our wiki service with the aims at increasing availability and scalability of the service. The problem we face is that all of this goes to waste when we need to upgrade the application, because in order to do that we need to shut down the entire cluster.

This is becoming more and more unacceptable as our user base grows because a 5-10min outage often translates to thousands of missed page views.

I understand that sometimes it is not (easily) possible to deliver this feature - mainly in cases when the new version of the application depends on a database schema, which is incompatible with the previous version.

On the other hand, changes like this don't happen very often and in many cases database schema changes often don't break the previous application (the old application just can't take advantage of the new schema features because it is not aware of them).

What I suggest is to allow cluster upgrades without the requirement to shut down the cluster whenever possible. IMO this means most of the time if the version of the application used in the cluster is not very outdated.

I realize that this will most likely require someone to watch schema changes or other changes that would make "hot" cluster upgrade impossible (incompatibilities in the serialized objects, coherence upgrades, etc), but it shouldn't be too difficult for anyone who is heavily involved in the Confluence development.

High availability is not an optional feature for Enterprise applications, so please consider this request and make necessary changes to the application as well as to the development/release processes to make Confluence more Enterprise friendly.
fields.summary: Support Confluence cluster upgrades without an outage

Scenario:  a monthly status page contains dynamically generated information from other sources.  eg a jira issue list.   After 6 months we want to see the first report, but it is executing the jiraissues list again and shows _current_ data.

  {panel}

The 'Raise Support Request' action is awesome. Though I haven't used it much, it seems to get us most if not all the information we could want/need to start resolving a problem situation:

http://localhost:8080/confluence/admin/raisesupportrequest.action

(The action that actually calls the request-creating action is called 'doraisesupportrequest.action'. The above action just displays the web page.)

Sometimes either Confluence is down completely or is just malfunctioning for any number of reasons (corrupt db) - it would be nice if i could tell a customer to just go into their 'bin' directory and run the 'raisesupportrequest.sh' script. The script might ask a quick question or two and then ask for confirmation that they wanted to submit a support request before actually sending the request. We might ask whether they want to use a configured mail server or the local mail user agent/mta (e.g. /usr/bin/mail), or even if they want us to zip the info packet into a zip on the filesystem that they could then get to us however they wanted.

Maybe it's possible to try and re-use the RaiseSupportRequestAction.java class. Things we might have to do:
1) Get path to java (using $JAVA_HOME, etc.)
2) Set up classpath
3) set up shell-script wrapper to ask at least one question ('Are you sure you want to submit a support request?').
4) Possibly do the add-on question for asking about which mail client/server to use.

This makes support easier on the end user, makes the Support Department more efficient (b/c we get the info we need, and we get it quickly, without spending time on the phone), and should ultimately make us more effective.

In theory, this could be relatively easy to accomplish.
fields.summary: Make 'Raise Support Request' functionality available via command-line, too -- in case (web-based) Confluence is not accessible

I feel like the 'Logging and Profiling' screen of the Administration interface should be persisted as soon as they are made, by default. If we want to provide a special 'Only change this in memory and do not persist'-type button, then that would be fine, but I would expect that the default behavior would and should be to persist any changes made (across server restarts).

Here is current documentation on Logging and Profiling settings:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF27/Working+with+Confluence+Logs#WorkingwithConfluenceLogs-FindingtheLogConfigurationFile

In the future I suppose we could allow folks to save particular logging/profiling 'configurations'.

With this change, I believe we should just get rid of the 'Save' button, as it would become superfluous. Again, any change you make would be persistent, by default, so using the 'Add Entry' button, for instance, would create/update a logging level that is changed immediately for runtime, but also changed permanently.

And this 'changes are persisted by default' philosophy would hold for the whole page - profiling, logging, etc.
fields.summary: Logging and Profiling changes should be persisted across Confluence restarts (Administration screens)

JNDI resources bound to the "env/comp" namespace are only visible to web container managed threads. Theads spawned by a web application (such as those that are used by the Quartz scheduler) are unable to find any resource bound in such a context and will fail with a {{NameNotFound}} exception.

This is problematic when such a job may cause the initialization of a lazy-init spring bean that requires a resource from that namespace.

We might need to do some reseach into either:

a) developing a mechanism whereby this lookup will succeed (unlikely I think)
b) Making sure that such a situation can be caught earlier.
fields.summary: Support access to JNDI resources from non container threads

At the moment a user encounters an error message like this:

---
CONFLUENCE
System Error
A system error has occurred - our apologies! Please contact your Confluence administrator to create a support issue on our support system at http://support.atlassian.com with the following information:

   1. a description of your problem and what you were doing at the time it occurred
   2. cut & paste the error and system information found below
   3. attach the application server log file (if possible). 

We will respond as promptly as possible.
Thank you! 
---

It would be great if an email could be sent with the complete error message to a pre defined e-mail address.
But it could be even better if automatically a new Jira issue could be created with the complete error message, without needing user input.

This way the system administrator will be notified about every error happening in the system with a full error log without the need to dig up all system log files searching for errors.

It could be usefull for Atlassian too if an Atlassian email address could be added to send the error messages so you will know what goes wrong 
with your products.
fields.summary: Auto Confluence error mail ingestion
